title: 103_s825
content: In cases involving acts of international terrorism, foreign sovereign immunity is not applicable. The term "act of international terrorism" is defined as a violent or dangerous act that violates the criminal laws of the United States or any state, and would be a criminal violation if committed within the jurisdiction of the United States or any state. The term "permanent resident alien" means an alien who is intended to intimidate or coerce a civilian population; to influence the policy of a government by intimidation or coercion; or to affect the conduct of a government by assassination or kidnapping. The term "permanent resident alien" refers to an alien lawfully admitted to the United States for permanent residence. Additional exceptions to Foreign State Immunity under Section 1605(a) of Title 28, United States Code, are amended by striking certain phrases and adding new paragraphs. The action is based on an act of international terrorism within the United States or outside if money damages are sought against a foreign state for personal injury or death to a United States citizen or permanent resident alien. The act occurred not more than 6 years previously and was committed or aided by a designated foreign state. The Secretary of State designated a foreign state repeatedly providing support for acts of international terrorism under section 40 of the Arms Export Control Act. Property subject to execution upon judgment. Section 1610(a) of title 28, United States Code, is amended by striking "or" at the end of paragraph (5); by striking the period at the end of paragraph (6) and inserting "; or"; and by adding at the end the. The execution relates to a judgment entered in a case based on an act of international terrorism within the United States or outside the United States if money damages are sought against a foreign state for personal injury or death to a United States citizen or permanent resident alien, which act occurred not more than 6. The act of international terrorism occurred not more than 6 years previously and was aided by a foreign state designated by the Secretary of State as repeatedly supporting acts of international terrorism under the Arms Export Control Act. Attachment of property prior to judgment entry is amended by redesignating paragraph (1) as paragraph (1)(A). Section 1610 of title 28, United States Code, is amended. The foreign state is not immune from jurisdiction under Section 1605. Exception to foreign sovereign immunity for cases involving torture, extrajudicial killing, aircraft sabotage, hostage taking, or genocide in a foreign state. Section 1605(a) of title 28, United States Code is amended to include cases where money damages are sought against a foreign state for personal injury or death of a US citizen caused by torture, extrajudicial killing, aircraft sabotage, hostage taking, or genocide committed by the foreign state or its officials. The amended Section 1605(a) of title 28, United States Code specifies that for an action to be maintained against a foreign state for personal injury or death of a US citizen, certain conditions must be met. These include the requirement that the individual was a US citizen at the time of the incident, exhaustion of remedies in the location of the incident, and bringing the action within 10 years. The amended Section 1605(a) of title 28, United States Code specifies that for an action to be maintained against a foreign state for personal injury or death of a US citizen, certain conditions must be met. These include bringing the action within 10 years after the cause of action accrues or within 18 months for acts of genocide occurring more than 10 years before the enactment of the paragraph. Terms like 'torture', 'extrajudicial killing', 'hostage taking', and 'aircraft sabotage' are defined in relevant international conventions. The term 'act of genocide' refers to conduct that would violate section 1091 of title 18 if done in the United States. SEC. 2. EXCEPTION TO IMMUNITY FROM ATTACHMENT. Amends Section 1610(a) of title 28, United States Code to allow attachment of property in cases where a foreign state is not immune under section 1605(a)(7). Also amends Section 1610(b)(2) to include cases where property is involved in the act upon which the claim is based. The amendments made by this Act apply to any cause of action before, on, or after the enactment date.
